sen.j: 鹿王院（ろくおういん）は京都市右京区嵯峨北堀町にある臨済宗系の単立寺院。
sen.e: Rokuo-in Temple is an independent Rinzai Sect Buddhist temple located in Saga Kitabori-cho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Rokuo-in Temple is an independent Rinzai Sect Buddhist temple located in Saga Kitabori-cho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Rokuo-in Temple is an independent Buddhist temple under the Rinzai Sect lineage located in Saga Kitabori-cho, Ukyo-ku Ward, Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 山号は覚雄山。
sen.e: Its honorific mountain prefix is Kakuyuzan.
Its honorific mountain prefix is Kakuyuzan.
Its sango (literally, "mountain name"), which is the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple is Kakuyuzan (Mt. Kakuyu).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 本尊は釈迦如来。
sen.e: The principal image is Shaka Nyorai.
The principal image is Shaka Nyorai.
The principal image is Shaka Nyorai (Shakyamuni).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 開基（創立者）は足利義満、開山（初代住持）は春屋妙葩（しゅんおくみょうは）である。
sen.e: The kaiki (founding patron) was Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, and the kaizan (first head priest) was Shunoku Myoha.
The kaiki (founding patron) was Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, and the kaizan (first head priest) was Shunoku Myoha.
The kaiki (founding patron) was Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, and the kaizan (first head priest) was Myoha SHUNOKU.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 鹿王院は、足利義満が建立した宝幢寺という寺の塔頭（たっちゅう）であった（塔頭とは、禅寺等で歴代住持の墓塔を守るために建立される寺院）。
sen.e: Rokuo-in Temple was a sub-temple (a temple established to protect the graves of successive chief priests) of Hodo-ji Temple which was founded by Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA.
Rokuo-in Temple was a sub-temple (a temple established to protect the graves of successive chief priests) of Hodo-ji Temple which was founded by Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA.
Rokuo-in Temple was a sub-temple (a temple established to protect the graves of successive chief priests) of Hodo-ji Temple which was founded by Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 宝幢寺は応仁の乱で廃絶し、その後は開山の塔頭であった鹿王院のみが残って寺籍を継いでいる。
sen.e: After Hodo-ji Temple disappeared as a result of the Onin War, the kaizan's sub-temple Rokuo-in Temple remained and took on the temple registration.
After Hodo-ji Temple disappeared as a result of the Onin War, the kaizan's sub-temple Rokuo-in Temple remained and took on the temple registration.
After Hodo-ji Temple disappeared as a result of the Onin War, only the kaizan's sub-temple Rokuo-in Temple remained and took on the temple registration.

sen.j: 室町時代の記録である『花営三代記』や、開山伝の『宝幢開山知覚普明国師行業実録』によると、宝幢寺の建立経緯は次のとおりである。
sen.e: The Muromachi period record "Kaei Sandai-ki"(Record of the Flowering Three Generations) and the kaizan's biography "Hodo Kaisan Chikaku Fumyo Kokushi Gyogo Jitsuroku" state the following regarding the founding of Hodo-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 『花営三代記』→"Kaei Sandai-ki"[Record of the Flowering Three Generations, www.informaworld.com/index/910734779.pdf]
sen.e: The Muromachi period record "Kaei Sandai-ki"(Record of the Flowering Three Generations) and the kaizan's biography "Hodo Kaisan Chikaku Fumyo Kokushi Gyogo Jitsuroku" state the following regarding the founding of Hodo-ji Temple.

The Muromachi period record "Kaei Sandai-ki" (Record of the Flowering Three Generations) and the kaizan's biography "Hodo Kaizan Chikaku Fumyo Kokushi Gyoko Jitsuroku" state the following regarding the founding of Hodo-ji Temple.

sen.j: 足利義満は康暦元年（1379年）のある夜、「そなたは今年中に大患をわずらうが、宝幢菩薩を祀る伽藍を建立すれば寿命が延びるであろう」との夢告を受けた。
sen.e: One night in 1379, Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA had a revelation in a dream that told him "You will fall ill this year and the only way to extend your life is to establish a temple for the worship of Hodo Bosatsu".

One night in 1379, Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA had a revelation in a dream that told him "You will fall ill this year and the only way to extend your life is to establish a temple for the worship of Hodo Bosatsu".

One night in 1379, Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA had a revelation in a dream that told him 'You will fall ill this year and the only way to extend your life is to establish a temple for the worship of Hodo Bosatsu.'
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: そのため、義満は自らの帰依する禅僧春屋妙葩（普明国師）を開山として一寺を建立することとし、康暦2年（1380年）完成した。
sen.e: This led Yoshimitsu to name as kaizan the Zen monk Shunoku Myoha (Fumyo Kokushi) to whom he had become devoted, and the temple was completed in 1380.
This led Yoshimitsu to name as kaizan the Zen monk Shunoku Myoha (Fumyo Kokushi) to whom he had become devoted, and the temple was completed in 1380.
This led Yoshimitsu to name as kaizan the Zen monk Myoha SHUNOKU (also known as Fumyo Kokushi) to whom he had become devoted, and the temple was completed in 1380.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 当初の寺号を興聖寺といい、後に宝幢寺（詳名は大福田宝幢禅寺）に改称したという。
sen.e: It is said that the original temple name was "Kosei-ji Temple" but that this was later changed to Hodo-ji Temple (formal name "Daifukuden Hodo-zenji Temple").
It is said that the original temple name was "Kosei-ji Temple" but that this was later changed to Hodo-ji Temple (formal name "Daifukuden Hodo-zenji Temple").
It is said that the original temple name was Kosei-ji Temple but that this was later changed to Hodo-ji Temple (formal name Daifukuden Hodo-zenji Temple).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えました。

sen.j: 鹿王院は、嘉慶元年（1387年）、開山の春屋妙葩の寿塔（生前に造る墓）を守る塔頭として創建されたものである（春屋の死去は翌嘉慶2年・1388年）。
sen.e: Rokuo-in Temple was founded in 1387 as a sub-temple to protect the grave of the kaizan after his death (Shunoku passed away in the following year of 1388).
Rokuo-in Temple was founded in 1387 as a sub-temple to protect the grave of the kaizan after his death (Shunoku passed away in the following year of 1388).
Rokuo-in Temple was founded in 1387 as a sub-temple to protect the grave of the kaizan after his death (Myoha SHUNOKU passed away in the following year of 1388).

sen.j: 宝幢寺は禅寺十刹の第5位に列せられる大寺であったが、応仁の乱で廃絶。
sen.e: Hodo-ji Temple was a dai-ji temple ranked 5th of the 10 great Zen temples but disappeared as a result of the Onin War.
Hodo-ji Temple was a dai-ji temple ranked 5th of the 10 great Zen temples but disappeared as a result of the Onin War.
Hodo-ji Temple was a large temple ranked 5th of the 10 great Zen temples but disappeared as a result of the Onin War.

sen.j: 塔頭の鹿王院のみが残った。
sen.e: Only the sub-temple Rokuo-in remained.
Only the sub-temple Rokuo-in remained.
Only the sub-temple Rokuo-in remained.

sen.j: 鹿王院は寛文年間（1661 - 1673）、酒井忠知（徳川四天王の一人である酒井忠次の子）によって再興され、忠知の子である虎岑玄竹（こしんげんちく）が中興開山となった。
sen.e: Rokuo-in Temple was restored by Tadatomo SAKAI (the son of Tadatsugu SAKAI, one of the Four Heavenly Guardians of the Tokugawa clan) between 1661 and 1673, and his son Koshin Genchiku was named restoration kaizan.

Rokuo-in Temple was restored by Tadatomo SAKAI (the son of Tadatsugu SAKAI, one of the Four Heavenly Guardians of the Tokugawa clan) between 1661 and 1673, and his son Koshin Genchiku was named restoration kaizan.

Rokuo-in Temple was restored by Tadatomo SAKAI (the son of Tadatsugu SAKAI, one of Tokugawa-Shitenno (four generals serving Ieyasu TOKUGAWA)) between 1661 and 1673, and Tadatomo's son Genchiku KOSHIN was named restoration kaizan.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 総門 - 切妻造、本瓦葺き。
sen.e: Somon gate: A kirizuma-zukuri style (gable roof) with a traditional tiled roof.
Somon gate: A kirizuma-zukuri style (gable roof) with a traditional tiled roof.
Somon gate: A kirizuma-zukuri style (gable roof) with a traditional tiled roof.

sen.j: 創建時に近い南北朝時代の建立と推定される。
sen.e: Estimated to have been constructed during the Northern and Southern Courts period soon after the temple's founding.
Estimated to have been constructed during the Northern and Southern Courts period soon after the temple's founding.
Estimated to have been constructed during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts soon after the temple's founding.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 本堂（開山堂） - 方三間（柱間が正面側面とも3間）、寄棟造、桟瓦葺き。
sen.e: Main hall (Kaizan-do): A hosangen (3 bays long x 3 bays wide) yosemune-zukuri style (hipped roof on a square building) building with a pantile roof.
Main hall (Kaizan-do): A hosangen (3 bays long x 3 bays wide) yosemune-zukuri style (hipped roof on a square building) building with a pantile roof.

Main hall (Kaizan-do): A hosangen (the length between front pillars and those of side pillars are three squared mats) yosemune-zukuri style (hipped roof on a square building) building with a pantile roof.

sen.j: 本尊釈迦如来坐像を安置する仏殿であるとともに、開山春屋妙葩の塔所でもある。
sen.e: The building serves as both Buddha hall housing the principal image seated statue of Shaka Nyorai and the burial place of the kaizan Shunoku Myoha.
The building serves as both Buddha hall housing the principal image seated statue of Shaka Nyorai and the burial place of the kaizan Shunoku Myoha.
The building serves as both Buddha hall housing the principal image seated statue of Shaka Nyorai and the burial place of the kaizan Myoha SHUNOKU.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 本尊像のほか、普明国師（春屋妙葩）像、足利義満像、虎岑和尚像などを安置する。
sen.e: In addition to the principal image statue, it also houses works including a statue of Fumyo Kokushi (Shunoku Myoha), a statue of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA and a statue of Koshin Osho.
In addition to the principal image statue, it also houses works including a statue of Fumyo Kokushi (Shunoku Myoha), a statue of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA and a statue of Koshin Osho.
In addition to the principal image statue, it also houses works including a statue of Fumyo Kokushi (Myoha SHUNOKU), a statue of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA and a statue of Koshin Osho.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 延宝4年（1676年）の建立。
sen.e: It was established in 1676.
It was established in 1676.
It was established in 1676.

sen.j: 舎利殿 - 方三間、宝形造（大棟のない四角錐状の屋根）桟瓦葺き、裳階付きの堂。
sen.e: Shariden (reliquary hall): A hosangen (3 bays long x 3 bays wide) hogyo-zukuri style (conical roof with no horizontal ridge beam) building with a pantile roof and a pent roof enclosure.
Shariden (reliquary hall): A hosangen (3 bays long x 3 bays wide) hogyo-zukuri style (conical roof with no horizontal ridge beam) building with a pantile roof and a pent roof enclosure.
Shariden (reliquary hall): A hosangen, hogyo-zukuri style (conical roof with no horizontal ridge beam) building with a pantile roof and a pent roof enclosure.
sen.cmt: 前出補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 堂内の厨子には源実朝将来と伝える仏舎利を込めた多宝塔を安置する（10月15日のみ公開）。
sen.e: The miniature shrine within the hall houses a two-tier pagoda containing Buddhist relics offered by MINAMOTO no Sanetomo (only open to the public on October 15th).
The miniature shrine within the hall houses a two-tier pagoda containing Buddhist relics offered by MINAMOTO no Sanetomo (only open to the public on October 15th).
The miniature shrine within the hall houses a two-tier pagoda containing Buddhist relics offered by MINAMOTO no Sanetomo (only open to the public on October 15).
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 宝暦13年（1763年）の建立。
sen.e: It was established in 1763.
It was established in 1763.
It was established in 1763.

sen.j: 庭園 - 舎利殿前に広がる、嵐山を借景とした庭園で、苔で覆われ、石組と植え込みを配した平庭式枯山水庭園である。
sen.e: Garden: The flat dry landscape garden incorporating the scenery of Arashiyama at the front of the reliquary hall is covered with moss and decorated with stone arrangements and shrubs.
Garden: The flat dry landscape garden incorporating the scenery of Arashiyama at the front of the reliquary hall is covered with moss and decorated with stone arrangements and shrubs.
Garden: The flat dry landscape garden incorporating the scenery of Arashiyama at the front of the reliquary hall is covered with moss and decorated with stone arrangements and shrubs.

sen.j: 舎利殿が建立された宝暦13年（1763）年頃の造園と推定される。
sen.e: It is estimated to date from circa 1763 when the reliquary hall was established.
It is estimated to date from circa 1763 when the reliquary hall was established.
It is estimated to date from around 1763 when the reliquary hall was established.

sen.e: Important Cultural Properties
Important Cultural Properties
Important Cultural Properties

sen.j: 絹本著色夢窓国師像（1906年重文指定）東陵永よの賛あり（「よ」は王篇に「與」）
sen.e: Color on silk portrait of Muso Kokushi (designated an Important Cultural Property in 1906) self-inscribed by Toryo Eiyo.
Color on silk portrait of Muso Kokushi (designated an Important Cultural Property in 1906) self-inscribed by Toryo Eiyo.
Color on silk portrait of Muso Kokushi (designated an Important Cultural Property in 1906) inscribed by Toryo Eiyo.

sen.j: 絹本著色夢窓国師像（1922年重文指定）

sen.j: 紙本著色釈迦三尊及三十祖像 明兆筆7幅
sen.e: 7 color on paper paintings depicting a Shakyamuni triad and the 30 founders by Myocho
7 color on paper paintings depicting a Shakyamuni triad and the 30 founders by Myocho
7 color on paper paintings depicting a Shakyamuni triad and the 30 founders, painted by Myocho

An imperial letter by Emperor Go-Daigo

sen.j: 鹿王院文書 1巻
sen.e: 1 scroll of Rokuo-in Temple document
1 scroll of Rokuo-in Temple document

sen.j: 金剛院文書 1巻

sen.j: 夢窓疎石筆臨幸私記（附天竜寺造営記）
sen.e: Muso Soseki's private records of an imperial visit (tsuketari: records of Tenryu-ji Temple's construction)
Muso Soseki's private records of an imperial visit (tsuketari: records of Tenryu-ji Temple's construction)

sen.j: 夢窓疎石墨蹟 2幅
sen.e: 2 works of calligraphy by Muso Soseki
2 works of calligraphy by Muso Soseki

sen.j: 上記の他、重要文化財の法華経（色紙経）8巻があったが、現在は奈良国立博物館の所蔵となっている。
sen.e: In addition to the above, 8 Important Cultural Property designated Lotus Sutra (on color paper) scrolls were also kept at the temple but these are currently deposited at Nara National Museum.
In addition to the above, 8 Important Cultural Property designated Lotus Sutra (on color paper) scrolls were also kept at the temple but these are currently deposited at Nara National Museum.
In addition to the above, 8 Important Cultural Property designated Lotus Sutra (on color paper) scrolls were also kept at the temple but these are currently deposited at Nara National Museum.

sen.j: 京都市右京区嵯峨北堀町
sen.e: Saga Kitabori-cho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City
Saga Kitabori-cho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City

sen.j: 京福電鉄鹿王院駅より徒歩2分。
sen.e: 2 minutes walk from Rokuo-in Station on the Keifuku Electric Railroad.
2 minutes walk from Rokuo-in Station on the Keifuku Electric Railroad.

sen.j: JR山陰本線（嵯峨野線）嵯峨嵐山駅より徒歩7分。
sen.e: 7 minutes walk from Saga Arashiyama Station on the JR Sanin Main Line (Sagano Line).
7 minutes walk from Saga Arashiyama Station on the JR Sanin Main Line (Sagano Line).
7 minutes walk from Saga Arashiyama Station on the JR Sanin Main Line (Sagano Line).

sen.j: 京都バス、京都市営バス下嵯峨バス停から徒歩5分。
sen.e: 5 minutes from the Kyoto Bus and Kyoto City Bus "Shimo-Saga" stop.
5 minutes from the Kyoto Bus and Kyoto City Bus "Shimo-Saga" stop.
